Opportunity [Description]: Join our WSIS+20 Working Group and help shape the future of our Internet vision and global policy. The WSIS+20 review is a key moment for digital development. Its outcomes will guide future UN action and stakeholder involvement.
Outreach Activity [Title]: WSIS+20 Working Group
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Alumni
Why It Matters: Ensuring the Internet remains secure, open, and trustworthy.

Opportunity [Description]: Hear from our community expert, Flávio Wagner from our Brazil Chapter, how the IGF has evolved over its 20 years of existence and join a lively discussion on which role the IGF should play in the future, and how.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Community Dialogue: The Evolution of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF)
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: The global community is taking stock of two decades of progress toward achieving the WSIS vision and the IGF mandate is up for renewal.

Opportunity [Description]: With Global Partners Digital (GPD) and a group of cross-stakeholders we have drafted Eight Practical Recommendations for the WSIS review with the aim of presenting tangible recommendations on how the WSIS co-facilitators can facilitate a transparent and inclusive process for the WSIS review.
Outreach Activity [Title]: WSIS+20 Five-Point Plan Follow-up: Eight Practical Recommendations
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members
Why It Matters: Ensuring transparency, inclusivity, and meaningful stakeholder engagement in the WSIS+20 review process.

Opportunity [Description]: The European Commission is forming an informal Expert Group to “focus on current and future technical challenges impacting lawful access to digital information in the context of criminal investigations”. It is looking for technically skilled professionals with domain-specific expertise, especially in cybersecurity, telecom, big data analysis, digital forensics, fundamental rights, and data technologies.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Expert Group for a Technology Roadmap on Encryption [European Commission]
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: There are concerns about how the roadmap frames strong encryption as a barrier to the EU's internal security and describes “lawful access” as an uncontested goal.

Opportunity [Description]: Learn about our new Advocacy Strategy—a bold, collaborative effort to strengthen our ability to influence the decisions that shape the Internet’s future. Whether you're a long-time advocate or just getting started, your voice and actions matter. Join us to discover how you can play a key role in advancing our shared mission and defending what makes the Internet a force for good.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Internet Society's New Advocacy Strategy – Session 1
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: As threats to an open, globally connected Internet grow, our collective voice and strategic action are more critical than ever.

Opportunity [Description]: Learn about our new Advocacy Strategy—a bold, collaborative effort to strengthen our ability to influence the decisions that shape the Internet’s future. Whether you're a long-time advocate or just getting started, your voice and actions matter. Join us to discover how you can play a key role in advancing our shared mission and defending what makes the Internet a force for good.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Internet Society's New Advocacy Strategy – Session 2
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: As threats to an open, globally connected Internet grow, our collective voice and strategic action are more critical than ever.

Opportunity [Description]: Thank you to those who have already endorsed our written contribution to the WSIS+20 Elements Paper. We have submitted our document to the United Nations and listed the initial endorsers on our website. The opportunity to endorse this contribution will remain open for a few days while we wait for the co-facilitators to release the WSIS+20 Zero Draft, which will be the next document in this process. You can endorse the contribution on behalf of your organization or in your personal capacity.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Endorse the Internet Society’s Contribution to the WSIS+20 Elements Paper
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni, Internet Pioneers
Why It Matters: Ensure our community’s voice contributes to shaping WSIS+20 outcomes that reaffirm the WSIS principles as critical enablers of an Internet for everyone.

Opportunity [Description]: The 2025 GEC grant applications will be accepted from 5 - 28 August (or until 50 grants have been distributed!). Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis by Internet Society staff. We encourage applicants to apply early as funds will be distributed on a first-come, first-served basis.
Outreach Activity [Title]: 2025 Global Encryption Day Grants
Who Can Get Involved: Chapter Leaders
Why It Matters: End-to-end encryption protects us all – we need to protect it!

Opportunity [Description]: This training series is designed to support your chapter in exploring new funding options beyond ISOC support, strengthening your financial resilience, and putting in place clear, actionable systems for resource mobilisation.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Fundraising and Financial Sustainability Training Series
Who Can Get Involved: Chapter Leaders
Why It Matters: Take important steps to becoming financially sustainable.

Opportunity [Description]:
The Internet Society requests that the Chapters Advisory Council (ChAC) identify one (1) volunteer to serve on the ISOC Nominations Committee AND one (1) volunteer to serve on the ISOC Elections Committee for the 2025-2026 nominations and elections cycle.

Find the volunteer requirements, time commitments, and more details about what each committee’s remit is below.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Serve on the Internet Society Board of Trustees Nominations and Elections Committees
Who Can Get Involved: Chapter Leaders
Why It Matters: Exercise your right to ensure that suitable candidates are slated for election.

Opportunity [Description]:
Funding availability varies based on the needs of the IXP or organization. Grants are available up to USD $70,000, and projects can run for up to 12 months.

Eligible funded activities include IXP equipment, reasonable operational, governance, and business development costs, IP transit capacity to promote local CDN cache content distribution, and technical, policy, and best practice capacity-building and workshops.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Sustainable Peering Infrastructure Funding Program
Who Can Get Involved: Chapter Leaders
Why It Matters: IXPs effectively improve the end-user experience and lower access costs while catalyzing the development of the local Internet ecosystem.

Opportunity [Description]: The Internet Society Foundation’s Beyond the Net Grant Program offers funding to support Internet Society Chapters to implement innovative projects that make a local impact by providing meaningful access to an open, trusted, and globally-connected Internet, as well as strengthening the Chapters’ presence in the surrounding community.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Beyond the Net Grant Program
Who Can Get Involved: Chapter Leaders
Why It Matters: Strengthen the impact of the Internet Society's mission and global initiatives with complementary local activities. Develop new and strengthen existing relationships and partnerships at the local level.

Opportunity [Description]: Join us for our first working session on the Internet Society's Advocacy Strategy. During this interactive session, we will work together to identify a roadmap and concrete steps for the community to implement Objective 1, with a special focus on developing effective tactics.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Working session: Internet Society's Advocacy Strategy
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members
Why It Matters: Help shape the Internet Society's advocacy strategy.

Opportunity [Description]: Be ready to join these interactive sessions. Together, we’ll shape the ideas and language we’ll use to defend the Internet and help make our vision a reality. Please circulate this invitation among your chapters and invite your colleagues to register for any of the two sessions. We scheduled them to cover different time zones; please choose the session that better accommodates your schedule.
Outreach Activity [Title]: WSIS+20 Zero Draft - Open Door Session (10AM UTC)
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: This Zero Draft is crucial because it contains the first set of proposed language that government delegations will use in their negotiations. The objective is to agree on a final document to be adopted in December during the WSIS+20 High-Level Meeting.

Opportunity [Description]: Be ready to join these interactive sessions. Together, we’ll shape the ideas and language we’ll use to defend the Internet and help make our vision a reality. Please circulate this invitation among your chapters and invite your colleagues to register for any of the two sessions. We scheduled them to cover different time zones; please choose the session that better accommodates your schedule.
Outreach Activity [Title]: WSIS+20 Zero Draft - Open Door Session (10PM UTC)
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: This Zero Draft is crucial because it contains the first set of proposed language that government delegations will use in their negotiations. The objective is to agree on a final document to be adopted in December during the WSIS+20 High-Level Meeting.

Opportunity [Description]: SIG topic leadership team provides an overview of the topic, campaigns for support and answers questions regarding their proposals with the Internet Society community.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Special Interest Group (SIG) Selection Process Q&A Open House #1
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Alumni
Why It Matters: Let your voice be heard, ask questions and be ready to vote on your favorite Special Interest Groups.

Opportunity [Description]: SIG topic leadership team provides an overview of the topic, campaigns for support and answers questions regarding their proposals with the Internet Society community.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Special Interest Group (SIG) Selection Process Q&A Open House #2
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Alumni
Why It Matters: Let your voice be heard, ask questions and be ready to vote on your favorite Special Interest Groups.

Opportunity [Description]: Join us at the Symposium for our exciting panels grouped around the most pressing Internet challenges we face today. The Fellows will share their amazing projects and their expertise on wider Internet issues, showcasing all they have learned throughout the program and beyond.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Early Career Fellowship Symposium 2025
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Alumni, Fellows
Why It Matters: The Internet Society Early Career Fellowship aims to empower the next generation of Internet champions around the globe who will advocate for the Internet to be for everyone, everywhere.

Action [CTA]: Contact your MEP (Member of the European Parliament)
Opportunity [Description]: Take part in a coordinated European effort to stop a new EU proposal that would break end-to-end encryption. Fight Chat Control, a citizen-led initiative, provides resources and support to contact your national governments and media to prevent the passage of this harmful "Chat Control" regulation.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Protect European digital privacy
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Alumni
Why It Matters: The "Chat Control" proposal would mandate scanning of all private digital communications, including encrypted messages and photos. This threatens fundamental privacy rights and digital security for all EU citizens.

Opportunity [Description]:
Some governments and organizations are pushing to weaken encryption, which would create a dangerous precedent that compromises the security of billions of people worldwide. Actions in one country that undermine encryption threaten all of us.

With over 400 members distributed across 103 countries, the Global Encryption Coalition promotes and defends encryption in key countries and multilateral fora where it is under threat. It also supports efforts by companies to offer encrypted services to their users.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Join the Global Encryption Coalition
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: Strong encryption is the foundation for the security of people, information and the Internet’s infrastructure.

Opportunity [Description]: The Board of Trustees invites the Internet Society community to join public sessions of its meetings as observers. These sessions enable attendees to listen in, but not participate in the discussion. See the agenda for the board meeting to determine which sessions are open to observers. Executive Sessions are closed meetings.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Internet Society Board Meeting No. 190
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: Stay informed, understand decision-making processes and help build trust, engagement and accountability.

Action [CTA]: Share your input on the policy brief
Opportunity [Description]: We look to the Internet Society community for comments and feedback on how to make the brief most useful for policymakers in their region and to ensure the brief sufficiently addresses the risks and potential benefits of age check requirements.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Input on Age Verification and Online Safety Policy Brief
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: New laws are being developed and implemented around the globe to require age checks for online services, usually to protect children online. As regulators set requirements for these age checks, commonly referred to as age verification, there is an opportunity to address challenges for the Internet from a global patchwork of laws with risks to people’s online privacy, security, and ease of access.

Opportunity [Description]: This second working session will focus on Objective 2 of the Internet Society Advocacy Strategy: Promote Affordable, Reliable, and Resilient Access: Create an environment that enables people and communities to connect themselves and promote an Internet that is affordable, reliable, and resilient. We will work together to identify a roadmap and concrete steps for our community to implement Objective 2, with a special focus on developing effective tactics.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Working Session: Internet Society Advocacy Strategy
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: Your participation will help us turn strategy into action — don’t miss the opportunity to shape the path forward!

Opportunity [Description]:
We will work together on designing a Community Hub, exploring how it can serve as a space to strengthen collaboration, knowledge exchange, and support among our communities. During this session:

We will review the main goals and opportunities for building a Hub; co-create the design and structure of the hub focusing on its value for our communities; identify next steps to move this idea forward collectively.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Co-Creation Session: Designing a Community Hub [Online Trust & Safety]
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Alumni
Why It Matters: Your participation is key to ensuring this hub reflects the priorities and realities of our communities.

Action [CTA]: Share your input on the policy brief
Opportunity [Description]: We look to the Internet Society community for comments and feedback on how to make the brief most useful and relevant in your regional contexts.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Input on Submarine Cable Resilience Policy Brief
Who Can Get Involved: Individual Members, Chapter Members, Chapter Leaders, Organization Members, Alumni
Why It Matters: Policymakers around the world are thinking about best practices to protect submarine infrastructure. The European Commission has published interesting work on this subject, triggered after the incidents involving cables in the Baltic Sea. There are interesting learnings from these and other practices around the world. This policy paper develops a set of recommendations to increase resilience, and to protect an infrastructure that despite invisible, is critical for the global Internet to exist.

Opportunity [Description]:
This open letter calls on the Irish government to reconsider their plans to undermine end-to-end encryption and calls on the Irish government to change its position on the issue at the EU level.

We are looking for organizations, companies, associations, and cybersecurity experts from around the world to sign on and demand that the Irish government protect strong encryption. Please share the call to sign on with your networks.
Outreach Activity [Title]: Open Letter: Irish Communications (Interception and Lawful Access) Bill
